Operations Center.From: Mary & John Holbrook
To: Staff, CAO (PUC)
Subject: Minnesota Power
Date: Wednesday, September 10, 2025 9:47:19 AM
You don't often get email from mnjholbrook@gmail.com. Learn why this is important
Dear Public Utilities Commission,
Please register my concern about the potential acquisition of Minnesota Power by BlackRockIncorporated.  I am a simple residential user but have grave concerns about a Mega-NationalCorporation purchasing the only utility electrical utility available to me in my part of the state.
I don't pretend to understand the complexities of the issue, but I beg you to do your due
diligence and to bear in mind your charge to represent Minnesota residence in the best way. Personally, I can't help but think that Minnesota Power going to Blackrock will not serve meor other state residents well.
I look to you and beg you to do your very best job representing us. Thank you.Mary Holbrook 
Nisswa, Minnesota

From: Robert Rutkowski
To: Staff, CAO (PUC) ; Sieben, Katie (PUC)
Subject: Block BlackRock’s $6.2B Acquisition of Minnesota Power
Date: Wednesday, September 3, 2025 6:53:15 PM
[You don't often get email from r_e_rutkowski@att.net. Learn why this is important at
https://aka.ms/LearnAboutSenderIdentification  ]
This message may be from an external email source.Do not select links or open attachments unless verified. Report all suspicious emails to Minnesota IT ServicesSecurity Operations Center.
________________________________
Katie Sieben, Chair
Minnesota Public Utilities Commission121 7th Place ESuite 350Saint Paul, Minnesota 55101Local: 651.296.0406 | Toll Free: 1.800.657.3782(651) 201-2250consumer.puc@state.mn.us, Katie.Sieben@state.mn.us
Re: Block BlackRock’s $6.2B Acquisition of Minnesota PowerDear Chair:
Today, elected officials and community members gathered outside of
Minnesota Power’s headquarters to call on the Minnesota Public UtilitiesCommission (PUC) to reject the utility’s private equity acquisition.Under the proposed acquisition, ALLETE, the parent company of MinnesotaPower, would no longer be a publicly traded company and would be sold totwo private equity investors, the Canadian Pension Plan Investment Board(CPP) and Global Infrastructure Partners, a subsidiary of BlackRock, theworld’s largest asset manager.
Folks from all over Duluth and across the Northland have been ringing
the alarm bells for over a year. Like most private equity vultures,these firms threaten to gut ALLETE and Minnesota Power, trying to pick
last bits of easy profit while Minnesotans will be burdened with higher
utility bills.
In July, an Administrative Law Judge (ALJ) found that the proposed
acquisition and private equity buyout of ALLETE is not in the publicinterest, and that the acquisition’s risks and harms outweigh thealleged benefits, resulting in net harm for ratepayers. In her findings,Administrative Law Judge Megan J. McKenzie wrote, “The nonpublicevidence reveals [GIP and CPP’s] intent to do what private equity isexpected to do – pursue profit in excess of public markets throughcompany control.”
Opponents to the acquisition include organizations who were parties in
the contested case proceeding, including Sierra Club, CURE, and the
Minnesota Citizens Utility Board, as well as the Minnesota AttorneyGeneral and Minnesota Power’s largest industrial customers. In addition,
an alliance of fifteen environmental, climate justice, and community
organizations voiced their opposition in a joint letter. The public also
spoke out overwhelmingly against the deal, with nearly 500 commentersasking the PUC to reject the private equity takeover.
Minnesota regulators and elected officials should be alarmed by the
differences in what BlackRock is saying publicly and privately, as notedin Judge McKenzie’s recommendation against the deal. Decisions about who
owns and operates Minnesota Power should be made with the public’s best
interest at heart, not dictated by shady Wall Street insiders workingbehind closed doors.
Advocates warn that if approved, the takeover would saddle Minnesota
Power with the private equity business model—notorious for aggressivecost-cutting, higher rates, and short-term profiteering. BlackRock,which already has major investments in fossil fuel infrastructure suchas the Rio Grande LNG terminal in Texas, has shown it prioritizesfinancial returns over community needs.
The acquisition also threatens to derail Minnesota’s clean energy
transition. While the state has a plan to achieve 100% carbon-free
electricity by 2040, opponents warn that private equity ownership could
slow progress on renewable projects, while driving up rates for familiesand businesses. In addition, the deal could leave Minnesota Powercustomers facing increased bills, compromised reliability, and reducedtransparency—all in service of Wall Street profits.
Yours sincerely,
Robert E. Rutkowski
2527 Faxon Court
Topeka, Kansas 66605-2086E-mail: r_e_rutkowski@att.net

Request 
Number 11Please provide the total annual average number of call center staff 
employed by Minnesota Power for the last 5 years and the state in which 
they primarily work.   
Response:  
The following chart illustrates the total average number of Minnesota Power call center staff 
(includes  Customer Care and Support Supervisors, Customer Care and Support  Representatives, 
and Quality Assurance Specialist s) for the last five years. All employees listed below have a 
primary work location in Minnesota. The average is calculated using the number of employees 
on the last day of every month.  
Staffing targets are informed by call volume and duration, with a full -time and part -time mix to 
provide flexibility to meet call response demands. Call Center representative job responsibilities 
range by utility from specialized (skills or topic -based rou ting) to universal (general call routing). 
Given its size in terms of customer count and the relative size of the Call Center, Minnesota 
Power has universal agents. Importantly, the Call Center has long -been an excellent entry point 
for a career at Minneso ta Power. Representatives primarily leave their roles for other internal 
opportunities. This is “good attrition” in the sense that the Company is retaining this talent. 
Though Minnesota Power and Superior Water Light & Power each have relatively small Call  
Center staffs, billing and contact center software is shared across the companies, providing for 
further flexibility in coverage for extreme events like storms involving outages. As contact 
center software solutions and communications channels continue to evolve, Minnesota Power 
will adapt accordingly to provide the excellent customer service its customers deserve and 
expect.

Requested From: Minnesota Power    Response Due:  September 4, 2025  
Analyst Requesting Information:   
 
Enclosed is the Minnesota Public Utilities Commission Information Requests PUC Nos. 8 -13 for 
ALLETE, GPP, and CIP. Please e -file the Company’s response by September 4, 2025.  Please 
indicate where, if at all, your responses include trade secret information . 
  
Request 
Number 13 Regarding the $50 million investment by 2030 in a “clean firm technology 
fund” proposed in the Company's settlement stipulation with the Department of Commerce:   
a. What process, or which specific proceedings, will Minnesota Power 
use to seek Commission approval for investments made out of this 
fund?   
b. By what date does Minnesota Power anticipate spending down the funds in this account?   
c. How many clean firm technology projects, and how much capacity (MW), does Minnesota Power anticipate will be made possible by this fund? Explain how this estimate was developed and provide examples of other clean firm project costs and/or research on expec ted technology costs to support your answer.    
d. How will Minnesota Power leverage or otherwise maximize the effectiveness and ratepayer benefits of this fund?  
 
 Response:  
 The Clean Firm Tech F und will be fully funded by 2030 but can be used beyond 2030 for 
compliance with the 2040 Carbon Free Standard.  
 
   
 
 
Witness: Jennifer Cady  
Response Date: 09/04/2025  
Response by: Jennifer Cady  
Email Address: jjcady@mnpower.com  
Phone Number: 218 -355 -3202  
 Witness: n/a 
Response Date: n/a 
Response by: n/a 
Email Address: n/a 
Phone Number: n/a 
 
 Witness: n/a 
Response Date: n/a 
Response by: n/a 
Email Address: n/a 
Phone Number: n/a 
 
 a. It is Minnesota Power’s intent that this f und will operate within existing commission 
processes, including but not limited to IRPs or resource acquisition proceedings.  
 
A project would be proposed by Minnesota Power through a regulatory petition for 
approval. The petition would identify the total cost of the project and why approval of it 
would be in the public interest. In that regulatory request, the Company would also 
request that the Commission approve use of the Clean Firm Tech Fund to fund the project in whole or in part, depending on size and eligibility.  
 
If the Commission were to approve both the project and full or partial funding through the Clean Firm Tech Fund, specific Commission -approved amounts from the Clean Firm 
Tech Fund would be used to write down the cost of projects for customers and be 
deducted from the overall cost recovery request in subsequent proceedings.  
 
b. The specific date by which the fund will be fully spent down will depend on the size, 
scope and cost of the projects ultimately approved by the Commission. One of the benefits of the Clean Firm Tech Fund is its flexibility to allow utilization of the fund upon identification of eligible projects that align with the requirements of the Carbon Free Standard. Depending on these factors, the funds could be spent down near the time of accrual if projects are identified and approved, but flexibility on timing is consistent with our commitment to meeting the standard while ensuring that projects are carefully evaluated and aligned with the fund’s purpose.  
 
c. It is the Company’s intent to deploy this fund to offset costs for customers as soon as an 
eligible project(s) is identified. However, a purpose of this Clean Firm Tech Fund is to 
provide a means of deploying clean firm technology as options and technologies continue to evolve. Therefore, at this time, it is difficult to identify what technologies, and therefore how many projects or what capacity, could be selected or proposed over the next fifteen years. The need to develop and support emerging clean firm technology is a key reason the settlement parties identified this Clean Firm Tech Fund as a key benefit to customers. Through the existing IRP processes, the Company will continue evaluating innovative and emerging technologies to continue serving customer s reliably 
and affordably while meeting Minnesota’s Carbon Free Standard.  
 
d. As stated above, Minnesota Power will leverage Minnesota’s robust resource planning and resource acquisition processes to identify resource types and commercially 
available projects that maximize benefits for customers and provide value to the system 
and will make proposals to the Commission so that individual projects and associated benefits for customers can be vetted. Minnesota Power recognizes that continued decarbonization of the system will require new infrastructure and resources, and the Company is dedicated to keeping bills as low as possible for customers throughout the transition. The Company will use this f und to offset the costs of Clean Firm Technology 
that customers would otherwise typically pay.

Headquarters  
In the initial filing ALLETE provided Attachment B which was entitled “AGREEMENT AND PLAN 
OF MERGER by and among ALLETE, INC., ALLOY PARENT LLC and ALLOY MERGER SUB LLC” 
dated May 5, 2024. On page 66 of that agreement Section 6.06(b)(i)(1) it states:  
“Headquarters. The Company will continue to maintain the headquarters of its regulated 
businesses in Duluth, Minnesota and Superior, Wisconsin.”  
After the separation that is proposed in 1.27 it is presumed Minnesota Power will be 
designated to be the Minnesota regulated entity and Superior Water Light & Power will be 
designated to be a Wisconsin regulated entity.  
Request 
Number 14 Will ALLETE or its subsidiary retain transmission and generation assets not 
within these two entities, but potentially still regulated by FERC or other 
jurisdictions?  
Response:  
Yes. Approval of the Acquisition will not change the ownership of these types of assets for any 
ALLETE business unit, nor the manner in which they are regulated. After the proposed 
separation of the Minnesota Power utility into a separate legal subsidiary of ALLETE, Minnesota 
Power and Superior, Water, Light & Power will continue to be separate regulated utilities 
subject to the same regulatory oversight as they are today. ALLETE also holds an investment in 
American Transmission Company LLC, which is a regulated entity that own s transmission assets, 
but is not related to Minnesota Power or Superior Water, Light & Power. All other ALLETE 
subsidiaries that currently own transmission and generation assets that are regulated by FERC 
or other jurisdictions will continue to own those assets, subject to the respective jurisdictions.

Analyst Requesting Information:   
Enclosed is the Minnesota Public Utilities Commission Information Requests PUC 14 – PUC 32 
for ALLETE, GPP, and CIP. Please e -file the Company’s response by September 4, 2025.  Please 
indicate where, if at all, your responses include trade secret informati on. 
Headquarters  
In the initial filing ALLETE provided Attachment B which was entitled “AGREEMENT AND PLAN 
OF MERGER by and among ALLETE, INC., ALLOY PARENT LLC and ALLOY MERGER SUB LLC” 
dated May 5, 2024. On page 66 of that agreement Section 6.06(b)(i)(1) it states:  
“Headquarters. The Company will continue to maintain the headquarters of its regulated 
businesses in Duluth, Minnesota and Superior, Wisconsin.”  
After the separation that is proposed in 1.27 it is presumed Minnesota Power will be 
designated to be the Minnesota regulated entity and Superior Water Light & Power will be 
designated to be a Wisconsin regulated entity.  
Request 
Number 16If these entities are “regulated entities” pursuant to the agreement and those 
entities’ headquarters were removed from Duluth, who would have standing to 
bring an action to enforce the agreement, what would be the specific action, 
what venue would such ac tion be brought in, and what would be any 
anticipated remedies for a breach of the agreement?  
Response:  
The Partners have committed in the Merger Agreement and the Settlement that the 
headquarters of Minnesota Power and SWL&P will not be moved.  
As with all commitments made by Petitioners that would be included in a Commission order 
approving the Settlement, there are multiple means to enforce this Order. These include by 
Commission investigation and further Order finding noncompliance and directi ng additional 
action; by enforcing specific performance in Court through a temporary restraining order, 
injunction, and/or declaratory judgment; and by seeking penalties or other relief in Court.   
The Commission has standing to pursue legal action in response to violations of its Orders, 
including conducting an investigation with or without a hearing and upon its own initiative. 
Enforcement is not, however, dependent on the Commission itself identif ying an issue; 
pursuant to Minn. Stat. § 216B.14 any interested stakeholder, including at minimum the 
Department, OAG, and other parties to this proceeding, could bring concerns about compliance 
or potential violations to the attention of the Commission.  
In addition to its authority to investigate and direct compliance, the Commission has standing 
and authority to seek injunctive relief and/or specific performance pursuant to Minn. Stat. § 
216B.54 and Minn. Stat. §  216B.64, and/or penalties consistent with  Minn. Stat. § 216B.57 
through.58.   Minn. Stat. §  216B.61 provides that civil actions to recover penalties shall be 
brought in Ramsey County District Court.  To eliminate any doubt, Settlement Paragraph 1.74 
provides that ALLETE and the Partners have submi tted to the jurisdiction of the Commission 
and courts in Minnesota to enforce or resolve any dispute arising from an applicable 
commitment set forth in the Settlement.    
In short, the Commission has multiple avenues to ensure that actions consistent with its Order 
be undertaken and to enjoin inconsistent actions, including through its own enforcement 
actions and through the courts.

Workforce and Labor Protections Enforcement  
In the July 11 Settlement Stipulation, Petitioners made commitments regarding “Workforce and 
Labor Protections” at paragraphs 1.56 to 1.62 including but not limited to prevailing wages, not 
to lay off employees, not to remove the existing leadership team, and not to reduce spending 
on the local community.  
Request 
Number 20For each of these paragraphs, identify how these commitments are 
enforceable.  
Response:  
Please see the responses to PUC IRs 0016 and 0021. 
The Commission also has extensive visibility into the Company’s activities and practices, that 
enables it to take action if/when needed.  For example, the Commission has the opportunity to 
evaluate employee headcount, wages and benefits, and spending on th e local community 
regularly through the Company’s rate cases.  Informally, the Company’s leadership team and 
community engagement are highly visible to the Commission and the community at large, such 
that changes are likewise highly visible. The Company ha s also committed to continue filing its 
annual Corporate Sustainability Report through Settlement Stipulation paragraph 1.65, which 
provides information regarding sustainability, social and governance matters, as well as the 
Company’s workforce and inclusi on efforts. The Commission may also investigate any concerns 
at any time through a proceeding initiated under Minn. Stat. § 216B.14, as described in 
response to PUC IR 0016 or may ask questions via discovery in any relevant docket before the 
Commission .
